entities.context: Ryan Salame (born 1993 (1993)) is an American entrepreneur who plead guilty to conspiracy to make unlawful political contributions and conspiracy to operate an unlicensed money transmitting business.

entities.name: FTX Digital Markets
entities.context: He was the CEO of FTX Digital Markets, the FTX subsidiary based in the Bahamas.

entities.context: He was the founder of the American Dream Federal Action super PAC.

entities.context: During the 2022 bankruptcy proceedings of FTX, it was revealed that the company loaned Salame $55 million.

relations.evidence: He was the CEO of FTX Digital Markets, the FTX subsidiary based in the Bahamas. He later became co-chief of FTX Digital Markets, FTX's Bahamas unit.
He was the founder of the American Dream Federal Action super PAC.
Salame grew up in Sandisfield, Massachusetts.
He attended high school at Monument Mountain Regional High School in Great Barrington.
He earned Bachelor of Business Administration in accounting from Isenberg School of Management
Bachelor of Arts in economics from the University of Massachusetts Amherst in 2015.
He later received a master's in finance from McDonough School of Business at Georgetown University in 2019.
Salame worked briefly for Ernst & Young.
In 2019, he started working for Alameda Research in Hong Kong.
During the primaries of the 2022 United States elections, Salame donated millions of dollars to Republican candidates.
During the 2022 bankruptcy proceedings of FTX, it was revealed that the company loaned Salame $55 million.
Salame's girlfriend Michelle Bond received $400,000 in consulting fees from FTX Digital Markets.
In April 2023 the FBI raided Salame's Potomac, Maryland home.
In September 2023, he pleaded guilty to violating campaign finance laws and operating an illegal money-transmitting business.
in May 2024 Salame was sentenced to 7.5 years in federal prison.
As of October 2024, he is incarcerated at FCI Cumberland in Maryland.
Before his incarceration, Salame gave an interview on Tucker Carlson's YouTube channel, claiming innocence. Carlson supported him.
He was the CEO of FTX Digital Markets, the FTX subsidiary based in the Bahamas.
